The Shoreside Infrastructure Project at the JLFT involves the delivery of civil, structural and electrical works to support the operation of electric ferry vessels starting in 2026 ("Project"). A general description of the four  components of the Project are as follows:        A. Foundation systems for three Electric Houses ("E-Houses") supplied by the Client's electrical system integrator ("Electrical System Integrator").         B. Underground ducts running from the street to the E-Houses, and from there to four JLFT docks. These underground ducts will carry the electrical wiring originating from Toronto Hydro on Queens Quay West and will terminate at the Automatic Shore Charging Systems ("ASCS", also known as "charging towers").        C. Upgrading of the four docks to accommodate new fenders, new mooring bollards and a new concrete pad on which to place the ASCS supplied by the Electrical System Integrator (As a part of the Project only two of the docks will be equipped with an ASCS, while the remaining two will have all enabling works completed for the future installation of ASCS).        D. Dismantling of the existing dolphin structure(s) to implement a new arrangement of six dolphins on independent piles, on which a rotating fender system and mooring bollards will be installed. This new arrangement of dolphins, including two gangways, will be used to guide vessels approaching the docks, to limit vessel movement during charging and loading operations, and to moor vessels.  The scope of Work and requirements for the Project are further described in Section 2 and elsewhere in this RFP. Time is of the essence for completion of the Project. The Project must be completed in October 2026 in advance of the arrival of the RoPax vessel (vessel that carries passenger and vehicles) in Q4 2026, in order to provide time for commissioning, trials and operations.

(1)The City is looking to tender, through a competitive process, a request for proposal for consulting services to support the Financial Planning Analysis Reporting System (FPARS) project. FPARS will transform the City to a higher-performing, results-based organization through the implementation of a new multi-year service and performance-based planning and budgeting process for the City.  It will further enhance customer service and transparency and accountability by re-organizing key service, financial, human resources and performance information for over 100 key City services provided to the public. FPARS is a best-practice improvement to planning, budgeting, monitoring and evaluation with the ability to assess services and their benefits to the City and Torontonians we serve.

Within the past seven (7) years, Suppliers must have achieved Substantial Performance, as defined in the Construction Act, as the lead contractor on municipal infrastructure contracts meeting the following criteria: 1.	Two (2) projects at least $1 million Canadian Dollars each in Final Contract Price (excluding taxes) with construction works in urban settings, with the locations identified (including major intersection, city/town, and province). 2.	One (1) project with installation of sewer by trenchless tunneling method for a minimum of 50 linear metres and minimum 675mm diameter pipe or a retained subcontractor meeting this requirement. 3.	One (1) project with watermain installation (≥250 mm diameter), including water services installation and/or replacement. 4.	Two (2) projects of at least $1 million Canadian Dollars each in Final Contract Price (excluding taxes) with at least two (2) of the following three (3) work types: sewers, watermains, and transportation road work. 5.	One (1) construction project in Type 4 soils (as classified in O. Reg. 213/91, s. 226 (5)) requiring trench wall support structures. 6.	One (1) project with roadway pavement, curb and sidewalk restoration and construction.  7.	One (1) project which required temporary diversion of sewer flows, water services and sewer laterals while maintaining flows and services to properties. 8.	One (1) project which required the removal, management and disposal of designated/hazardous materials, including asbestos.  AND  b.	Mandatory experience criteria for key staff on this project (Project Managers and Superintendents) are as follow: 1.	One (1) Project Manager with:  a.	A minimum of five (5) years of experience as a "Project Manager" in municipal infrastructure projects, and  b.	A degree in engineering or a diploma in engineering technology.  2.	Two (2) superintendents, one (1) with a minimum of ten (10) years of experience in municipal infrastructure construction.  3.	In addition to meeting the definition of Qualified Person under O.Reg. 153/04 and O.Reg. 406/19, one (1) Contractor's Qualified Person (QP) with the following qualifications:   a.	A minimum 10 years of work-related soil management experience for projects of similar size, scope, and complexity to the Work;  b.	A current licence in good standing with a public body within the province of Ontario such as Professional Engineers of Ontario or Professional Geoscientists of Ontario;  c.	Knowledge of Environmental Protection Act (Ontario), O. Reg. 153/04 and O. Reg. 406/19;  d.	Knowledge of relevant federal and Ontario environmental policies, procedures and legislation/regulations;  e.	Experience liaising with other speciality consultants, contractors, agencies, and governmental authorities; and,  f.	Experience with similar projects in the province of Ontario related to excess soil.   	Suppliers must complete the key staff experience fields in Ariba. Suppliers must also upload resumes for each of the four (4) key staff (one project manager, two superintendents and one Contractor's QP as per above) to demonstrate that the mandatory experience and qualification criteria have been met.

.1	This Request for Quotation (the “RFQ”) is an invitation by the City of Toronto (the “City”) to prospective Suppliers to submit bids for the non-exclusive supply, delivery, maintenance and repair of RAE Systems Air monitoring equipment and accessories to Toronto Fire Services (TFS), as further described in Part 3 and the Contract (the “Deliverables”).    .2	In accordance with the Canada European Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), bids will only be accepted from Canadian Suppliers and Trade Partner Suppliers. Bids from USA Based Suppliers will be deemed non-compliant and rejected. .3	In accordance with the Canadian Free Trade Agreement (CFTA) Bids will only be accepted from Canadian Suppliers. Any bids from Trade Partner Suppliers, Non-American Suppliers and US Based Suppliers will be deemed non-compliant and rejected. .4	The Successful Supplier will be required to either (i) execute a Contract, or (ii) acknowledge the Contract as contained in the City's purchase order for the provision of the Deliverables. Suppliers should review the terms and conditions set out in Part 2 (FORM OF AGREEMENT) to understand the Contract being entered into with the City. It is the City’s intention to enter into a Contract with only one (1) legal entity.  The term of the Contract is to be for a period of one (1) year from date of award, with an option in favour of the City to extend the agreement on the same terms and conditions for an additional term of up to four (4) additional separate one (1) year periods.  .5	The City reserves the right, at its sole and absolute discretion, to not award some or all of the Optional Extension Years as part of the award of the contract to the successful Supplier, in the event that the cumulative cost of such Optional Extension Years combined with the cost of the original contract term exceeds the monetary thresholds established by the Canada European Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA). .6	This RFQ shall be interpreted in accordance with Section 3.14 (Definitions and Interpretation) and the City's Policies and Legislation. .7	Invitation to submit a Bid, including participation in any pre-qualification, request for information or other similar process or exchange of information prior to the RFQ, does not imply that a Supplier is automatically prequalified to meet the requirements of the RFQ or that the factors which were examined during such process or exchange may not be re-examined or re-evaluated by the City during the consideration and selection process for this RFQ. It will still be necessary for the Supplier to demonstrate its qualifications through the RFQ process.

The Capital Project Design and Delivery Section (CPDD) of the Parks & Recreation Division (P&R) provides capital project design and delivery services for PFR's extensive and diverse assets. Due to the large volume of unanticipated/emergency work required, and in an effort to be able to service its clients in a reasonable and timely manner, the City reserves the right to enter into a Contract with two (2) successful General Contractors who have the highest evaluation scores (Part4 -Form B Technical Proposal and Qualifications) meeting mandatory requirements to perform the tasks associated with this Request for Proposal (RFP). Should the General Contractor have satellite locations available, this information must be provided by the General Contractor (Part 4 - Form C) for Award consideration. The work is spread out in two geographical areas, i.e. North & East Districts, and South (including Toronto Islands) & West Districts and one contractor will be hired for each geographical after evaluation by the City. Suppliers are required to indicate their preference of geographical area in their submission. The proponent with the highest score will be assigned their preferred geographical area while the second highest will be assigned the other geographical area. The City will make every effort to ensure an even distribution of work between the two successful Contractors. The Contractor must remain flexible to work at any geographical area. The City reserves the right to allocate any contract to one of the successful contractors, irrespective of the geographical area.  The term of the Contract is to be for a period of (3) three years from the date of award, with an option to extend the agreement on the same terms and conditions for an additional two, one (1) year terms. The option to renew is at the discretion of the City and will be subject to budget availability and General Contractor's performance.

Purpose of this Notice The City of Toronto is providing advanced notice of an upcoming multi-package   procurement for waste management services in support of its role as a Host City for the FIFA World Cup 2026™.  This procurement will cover a full lifecycle service scope-planning, operations, and demobilization-across multiple sites, including BMO Field, the FIFA Fan Festival, and public areas. Suppliers will be required to manage three waste streams (organics, recyclables, garbage), aligned with the City of Toronto and FIFA's sustainability goals.  Event Scope Overview Waste management services will span the full event lifecycle, including: •	Planning Phase - Participation in the Waste Management Working Group (WMWG). •	Site Load-In & Setup - Deployment of bins, signage, and infrastructure. •	Operational Period - Active service on match days, at the Fan Festival, and at other support sites. •	Demobilization - Site clean-up and post-event waste reporting. Waste Streams & Sustainability Goals Accommodate and track the following waste streams across all FWC26 Host City-serviced sites, including: •	BMO Field (Stadium) •	FIFA Fan Festival Site •	Venue Specific Training Site (Centennial Park& BMO Training Ground) •	Last Mile public spaces (e.g. pedestrian routes, access corridors near stadium)  Waste Streams include: •	Organic Waste (e.g. food scraps, compostable service ware) •	Recyclables (e.g. paper, plastics, cans, bottles) •	General Waste (non-recyclable) Suppliers should demonstrate capability in source separation, contamination control, and diversion reporting. Opportunities to increase diversion rates through public education, signage, and green workforce integration   will be encouraged. Anticipated Work Packages (Subject to Refinement) 1. Stadium Waste Haulage Services (BMO Field) •	Haulage of general waste and recyclables on 6 match days (~45,000 attendees per match). •	Supplier must supply appropriate roll-off bins (e.g. 20-40 yard) for waste and recycling containment. •	No on-site handling; pick-up and transport only. •	Estimated waste: 1.3 kg/person/day. 2. FIFA Fan Festival - Full Waste Management Services •	Full waste service across 25-27 days of activity (~20,000 - 40,000 attendees daily). •	On-site operations, bin servicing, litter picking, emergency cleaning, haulage, and public education. •	Suppliers must manage all three waste streams and support diversion targets. 3. VSTS Training Site (Centennial Park) - Waste Haulage •	Pick-up and transport only across 20-22 days of activity (~200-300 attendees daily). •	Modest waste volumes. 4. Last Mile Litter Collection & Bin Servicing •	Haulage of general waste and recyclables on 6 match days. •	Waste and litter control services across designated Last Mile pedestrian routes near the stadium on all 6 match days. •	Placement and servicing of public waste and recycling receptacles along key corridors (e.g. transit hubs, pedestrian walkways, fan congregation zones). •	Timely bin emptying, litter picking, and emergency response (e.g. spills). •	Supplier must supply appropriate roll-off bins (e.g. 20-40 yard) for waste and recycling containment. •	Coordination with the City's Last Mile Operations Plan to ensure alignment on crowd flow and service windows. •	Reporting on volumes and observed contamination issues encouraged. 5. Collection and processing of organics from all venues. •	Haulage to licensed composting or anaerobic digestion facilities. •	Supplier must provide documentation confirming acceptance and processing of all materials at an approved facility. •	Optional provision of on-site composting systems. •	Diversion tracking, and contamination mitigation required. 6. Project Management •	An assigned Project Manager to oversee delivery and integration across all sites. •	Actively participate in the Waste Management Working Group (WMWG) and provide updates to the wider group on assigned work packages. •	Daily and cumulative diversion tracking, contamination monitoring, and reporting. This RFSQ is an invitation to qualify experienced General Contractors for the provision of contracting services for the construction of David Crombie Park Improvements and The Esplanade and Mill Street Connection (cycle track, intersection changes, streetscape improvements), demonstrating exemplary experience in the construction of complex park landscapes which emphasize superior project construction administration skills and high quality workmanship, and demonstrating delivery of road construction projects and related infrastructure such as cycle tracks, sidewalks and streetscaping elements, line painting and signals for the Transportation Services scope of work. Respondents must also demonstrate a commitment to delivering completed projects in an efficient manner and schedule, including phased construction over more than one season.  All interested Respondents are invited to submit a Response for future eligibility to provide General Contracting Services on a one-time project basis.  General Scope of Work  David Crombie Park General scope of work includes but is not limited to:  a.	Demolition, excavation, and grading: Limited demolition. Excavation and grading including management of soils in accordance with ministry regulations. b.	Demolition and removal of small building: demolition and removal of small building with glass and metal structure that leads to underground route to adjacent school building across The Esplanade; building will be removed and capped with structural slab; no change to below-grade condition of tunnel connection. c.	Grading and drainage: Changes to grading and drainage piping in one block of the park. Most of park grading and drainage remains in existing condition.  d.	Water Features: Refurbishment of existing ornamental water feature with new mechanical and electrical, new basin surround; refurbishment of existing wading pool with new mechanical and electrical, new paving.  e.	Irrigation: drip and sprinkler irrigation for selected planters. Includes connection to existing water service and a backflow preventer. f.	Lighting and Electrical: new Toronto Hydro service in the park blocks to be provided by the City, new lighting and wiring to be coordinated with new service panel install, one block has existing electrical service to be upgraded with new electrical cabinet. New light standards and feature LED strip lighting connected to new service. g.	Softscape: variety of planting including large caliper trees, standard caliper trees, and trees planted in soil cells, shrubs, understory planting, climbing vines, and sodded lawn.  h.	Hardscape: High quality concrete paving, and a variety of paving materials and treatments including asphalt paving and unit pavers.  i.	Play areas: two large playgrounds will be rebuilt with standard and custom play equipment including poured in place resilient rubber surfacing with subsurface drainage.  j.	Indigenous Placekeeping Elements include carving of four cardinal-sign large boulders by an Indigenous artist, construction of a sunken sacred fire pit, application of stencil patterns created by Indigenous artist (the artists will chosen by the City in advance of the RFT and carried as a cash allowance) k.	Site Furnishings: install new seating (benches, tables and chairs, picnic tables) including seat toppers on existing concrete walls l.	Others:  •	Cleaning and repair of existing concrete seat walls and concrete arches. •	Cleaning, painting and refurbishment of existing metal fencing and gates. •	Wood amphitheatre seating.  •	Large granite boulders install. •	Other Site furnishings including city standard trash bins and bike rings  The Esplanade and Mill St. Connection General scope of work includes but is not limited to:  •	Cycle tracks •	Pavement markings •	Traffic signal works •	Intersection upgrades •	Green infrastructure (i.e. bulb-outs with planting) •	Streetscape elements (i.e. seating, tree planting, speciality pavers etc.)  For Transportation Services, the project features an upgraded cycle track along The Esplanade, and a protected intersection at The Esplanade and Lower Sherbourne Street. It also includes right-of-way safety improvements such as raised pedestrian and bikeway crossings, curb extensions and corner radii adjustments along The Esplanade and on local streets (George Street and Frederick Street). . It will also upgrade the existing promenade walkways on the north side of The Esplanade and along Princess Street, where feasible.. All of this work is in the public right-of-way and integrated with the park design.   The TS project's goals are to:  • Enhance safety for everyone • Make walking, cycling and taking transit more attractive  • Maintain and improve access to local and citywide destinations

The Western Beaches Tunnel (WBT) system (refer to Figure 1) collects and treats combined sewer overflows (CSO) and stormwater from ten existing CSO and storm sewer outfalls. Constructed in the late 1990's, the system consists of a 3 metre diameter, 3.6 kilometre long storage tunnel that runs parallel to Lake Ontario, from approximately Parkside Drive to Strachan Avenue, with three main storage shafts (approximately 25 metres diameter by 35 to 40 metres deep) located at the Battery Park (785 Lake Shore Blvd. W.), Cowan (1075 Lake Shore Blvd. W.) and Glendale (1725 Lake Shore Blvd. W.) sites, six drop shafts, ten sewer interception chambers, nine lake isolation chambers, and a pumping station with ultra-violet (UV) disinfection system. The Parkside Drive sewer interception chamber (located about 130m west of the Glendale sewer interception chamber) includes an approximate 45m long open channel emergency overflow to the lake. The entire WBT system has an 85,000 cubic metre storage volume and was designed to improve water quality conditions at the City of Toronto’s nearby swimming beaches and along Toronto's waterfront.     This WBT Phase 2 construction project involves a complete retrofit of the existing Battery Park pumping station building. As an overview, the general work scope includes removal of all electrical, mechanical, HVAC, process, instrumentation, SCADA/automation, shaft access stairs, pumping system, tunnel flushing system, shaft sediment fluidization system and UV system equipment (the pumping station structure including the floors, walls and roof will be retained) and replacement with all new equipment. Related, but significantly less extensive, work is also required at the Cowan, Glendale and Parkside sites. A more detailed summary of the work scope consists of, but is not limited to, the following major work: 1.	Management of the construction works and integration with ongoing facilities and operations. 2.	Provision of all temporary measures and works (including equipment, piping, civil, mechanical, electrical, instrumentation and control) to complete work under this Contract including disposal of any contaminated soil and groundwater, and management of any sewer infiltration/leakage flows. A major temporary measure will be the construction and operation of a temporary pumping system capable of pumping up to 300 L/s to remove inflow/infiltration and overflow water that enters the WBT system so that construction work can proceed under dry conditions within the system. 3.	Demolition, removal and modification of the existing equipment, piping, structures, mechanical, electrical, instrumentation and control systems as shown on the drawings and described in the specifications. Disposal of removed unwanted equipment, piping, structures, excavated materials, dewatering water and contaminated materials off site resulting from the demolition, removal, excavation and construction works. Finish the removal and modification surfaces to match adjacent surface conditions by filling, grout, painting or other required means. 4.	Coordination and cooperation with the City is required for temporary measures and for continuous operation of the facilities, maintenance and access, connections to the existing facilities, installation of new equipment, buildings, structures, mechanical, electrical and control systems. Coordinate mechanical, process systems and electrical installations. 5.	Furnish, install and/or supervise installation, start-ups, testing, corrections if needed, commissioning and training. The project work scope includes:  (A)	Replacing the existing two pump system with 2 decant pumps and 2 dewatering pumps, including pump mounts and pump retrieval systems;  (B)	Install new actuators for the existing three flushing gates and the new lake water intake chamber isolation gate. Install a new trash rack and trash basket in the lake water pump chamber.; (C)	Installing new grit/sediment fluidization systems in the Battery Park shaft. There will be one fluidization system for the shaft that is gravity fed with lake water and one fluidization system for the pump sump that is pump fed with lake water. Installation of new stairs and a perimeter sediment/rock barrier wall around the pump sump.; (D)	Replace the existing UV system with a new up-to-date system including modifications to the UV forebay, grating and effluent weir; (E)	Installation of new composite samplers that have separate sample pumps and recirculation lines; (F)	Modifications to the existing Battery Park storage shaft roof hatches and provision of new hatches for equipment removal, access and cleaning; (G)	Replacement of the existing stairs in Battery Park shaft with new FRP stairs; (H)	Replacement of existing stairs at Glendale shaft with new FRP stairs: (I)	The installation of new stairs in the Cowan shaft with new FRP stairs; (J)	The supply of travel restraint systems on the upper ring channel inside the Battery Park shaft and training for use
Wards: Ward 4 Parkdale-High Park,Ward 10 Spadina-Fort York

This RFP is an invitation by the City of Toronto (the 'City') to prospective suppliers to submit Bids for a proponent to implement a Youth Skills Development Pilot Program (Pilot) in the Little Jamaica community in Toronto. The Pilot will be a 1.5-year initiative focused on developing financial literacy skills and result in employment in various opportunities in the financial services industries for youth ages 16-29 years old who reside in or are connected to the community of Little Jamaica. The Pilot is inclusive for youth who identify as Black, Indigenous, and/or racialized. The Pilot will begin in 2022 and commence in December 2023. Little Jamaica is located in the City of Toronto on Eglinton Avenue West from Keele Street west to Marlee Avenue. The community of Little Jamaica is located in the City of Toronto from Castlefield Avenue south to Rogers Road and Keele Street west to Marlee Avenue

Orders may not commence immediately upon contract initiation. .3	The procurement and resident care teams considered the following key factors when developing the product specifications outlined in subsequent sections:  •	Resident comfort;  •	Pressure relief; •	Resident safety; •	Durability and quality; •	Infection control and ease of cleaning; •	Fire safety / flame resistance. .4	SSLTC requires pillows of one standard size. .5	SSLTC requires comforters of one standard size (twin size).  .6	SSLTC may also purchase other bedding products, on as-needed basis. Those may include, but are not limited to: comforters in other sizes, bedspreads of various sizes and styles.  .7	Please note that detailed specifications for those additional items SSLT may or may not purchase will not be provided in the Part 3 of this RFQ. Instead, up to 20 percent of the total contract value will be allocated for miscellaneous bedding products. Please refer to Part 5 of this RFQ for more details. .8	Purchases under the miscellaneous category will be made at the discretion of the City, based on availability of suitable products in the catalog of the successful supplier, alignment with quality expectations, and competitive pricing. .9	SSLTC reserves the right not to purchase miscellaneous items if the available options will not meet requirements in terms of quality, specifications or cost. .10	SSLTC is seeking a Supplier who can provide high-quality products that align with these key considerations to support the health and safety of residents.

This RFSQ is an invitation by the City of Toronto to prospective Respondents to qualify for future eligibility of supplying natural gas.  The City wishes to establish a roster (Multi-use Roster List with Second-Stage Competition) of pre-qualified suppliers possessing acceptable credit rating, experience and capabilities with respect to the supply of natural gas to the City.  The City intends to enter into Master Agreements (refer to Part 4 - Form of Agreement for a specimen) with at least three (3) and no more than a total of five (5) qualified Respondents to form the Roster.  All Suppliers on the Roster will be invited to bid on subsequent Request for Quotations (RFQs) for the supply of natural gas as requested by the City from time to time.  The term of the Roster will be for an initial period of three (3) years with  additional two (2) separate one (1)-year option periods at the City's discretion.    In order to be considered for evaluation, Respondents or its guarantor must have an acceptable credit rating that is not less than BBB(-) from S&P or Fitch Ratings, Baa3 from Moody's or BBB(low) from DBRS.    Current Roster expires on February 28, 2025. Suppliers on the current Roster are required to respond to this RFSQ to be re-prequalified for the new Roster. Should an existing Supplier on the current Roster be selected for the new Roster as a result of this RFSQ, the existing Master Agreement will be valid and the City does not expect any changes

Solicitation Document Description: Background  Willowdale Park, located at 75 Hollywood Ave, North York, ON M2N 5S9, is being improved in line with the design developed in collaboration with the local Councillor, residents, other stakeholders.    The purpose of this Request for Tender (RFT) is to provide full general contracting construction supply and installation services for the Landscape Redevelopment Project, Willowdale Park Improvements, as required by the City of Toronto, Parks & Recreation, Capital Projects Division. It is expected that the winning bidder will comply with the standards, guidelines, policies and procedures of the relevant authorities and divisions, as well as with all applicable codes, by-laws, and regulations.   The park is home to the North York Tennis Club. Along with tennis facilities the park currently features a playground, splash pad, pathways, parking lot, open lawn areas and mature trees. There are plans to upgrade the park with a new playground and outdoor exercise station, as well as a new shade structure, seating, community message board, and bottle filling station. Existing concrete pathways will be redone with new concrete. The tennis courts will receive new fencing, lighting and repairs to the existing retaining wall. Excavation will be required to accommodate the construction of these features and upgrades.  Summary of work   Services expected to be completed include, but are not limited to, grading, drainage, site servicing, demolition & removals, clearing and grubbing, site/tree protection fencing, concrete flat work and concrete curbs/walls/pavements, walkways, armour stone walls, concrete ramp, concrete stairs, asphalt/unit paving, splash pad, fencing, tree and shrub planting, sodding, seating, playground, outdoor fitness, lighting, and shade structure. As most of the work is landscape architectural in nature and involves the extensive renovation of existing landscape elements, the contractor team shall be led by a landscape contractor experienced in leading and coordinating landscape renovation projects, with experience in playground installation.

•	 The City of Toronto requires professional engineering services to conduct a study that will define causes, assess potential impacts, and provide direction on mitigation measures regarding hydraulic transients in the water distribution and transmission systems for pressure districts 1E, 2E, 3, 3E, 4, 4S and 5S (the Study Area.) •	To merge and validate a hydraulic water model for pressure districts 1, 1E, 1W, 2, 2E, 3, 3E, 4, 4S and 5S that will be used for creating a transient model for the study area for assessing adequacy of existing surge protection devices and current operating strategies of facilities and the transmission and distribution water systems. •	To develop a monitoring plan for collecting data in the field including continuous pressure logging, C-factor testing, fire flow testing, and flow monitoring to be used to validate the aforementioned hydraulic model; to calibrate and validate a new water transient model for the study area; and finally, to implement the monitoring plan in the field. •	To create, calibrate and validate a water transient model for the study area to assess impact and risk of transients in the water transmission and distribution systems, provide surge protection for future system conditions to accommodate future population growth and expansion of the water system, and recommend schedule and cost for capital implementation of recommended protection measures. •	To prepare a city-wide plan for the installation of temporary and permanent sensors in facilities and the distribution and transmission watermains to be implemented by the City after completion of the study. Make a recommendation for number of sensors, location, cost and implementation stages. Purchase and installation of sensors will be done by the City and will not be part of this study.

As part of its overall security strategy, the City of Toronto ("the City") intends to procure a Managed Security Services Provider (the "MSSP") to deliver comprehensive security operational and monitoring services of the City's network environment and all its assets to prevent, detect, respond, mitigate and recover from cyber security threats and events. The MSSP is expected to partner with the City in co-managing its existing SIEM, EDR and NDR security technologies, as well as to provide new solutions where necessary to meet requirements. The proposed solution will provide 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, 365 days per year (24x7x365) mature Security Operations Centre (SOC) which will manage the City's existing SIEM, EDR and NDR solutions as well as any new solutions that are deployed to meet requirements. The proposed solution will also include a 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, 365 days per year (24x7x365) comprehensive security incident response service which encompasses detection, analysis, evidence collection, containment, eradication, remediation, recovery and support with on-site incident management.  Services to be delivered as part of the MSSP solution include forensics services support for investigations, threat intelligence, device management, ongoing vulnerability assessments and reporting (collectively referred to as the "Solution").
Division: Office of the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)

The purpose of this RFP is to select qualified consultant(s) ("Consultant") to complete an evaluation of supportive housing programs in the City of Toronto. New supportive homes are intended for people experiencing or at risk of homelessness and are often prioritized for Torontonians experiencing chronic homelessness. Supportive housing programs are intended to help residents maintain their housing and prevent returns to homelessness, assist them with living as independently as possible, and improve their health and well-being. New supportive housing is a core component to ensuring Toronto is advancing towards the progressive realization of the right to adequate housing. Under the HousingTO 2020-2030 Action Plan, the City of Toronto has a target of approving 18,000 new supportive homes by 2030.

The purpose of this RFP is to select a qualified professional consultant team, led by a landscape architect, to provide full professional and technical services for the design and implementation of park improvements for Barbara Hall. The City requires professional services from a single, qualified consulting firm, or a consulting team comprised of a number of firms of varied disciplines, with exceptional skills in consulting with municipal clients, a commitment to design excellence and a proven ability to design and implement innovative and high-quality community parks with efficient and effective contract administration skills.

This RFP is an invitation by the City of Toronto (the "City") to prospective suppliers to submit Bids for the Operation and Maintenance of a Passenger Transportation Shuttle Service at High Park and other potential locations to support the goals of the High Park Movement Strategy and provide an affordable service to improve park users' accessibility to key destinations within the Park.  The City is seeking for solutions that can meet mandatory requirements and major deliverables such as:  •	Procurement and provision of a fleet of shuttle vehicles that can transport groups of passengers in an environmentally friendly manner, along with the provision and maintenance of appropriate infrastructure to facilitate service and storage.  An electric fleet or a commitment to have plans to transition to an electric fleet is expected. •	Operation and maintenance of a regular daily shuttle service from April 1 to October 31 annually through the term of the contract, with the plans to pilot and provide winter service on weekends and eventual expansion to regular year-round service as demand requires and to improve accessibility. •	Service delivery with a focus on affordability, accessibility, customer service excellence. •	Safe operation of vehicles around all park users (including those who drive, walk, cycle, or use other mobility devices) and wildlife within the Park. •	The capability to navigate the travel network (pathways, roadways, pavements, etc.), terrain and road conditions. •	Ability to animate the park and serve as a major attraction enhancing park experience. •	Business strategy to build infrastructure, acquire assets, operate service and sustain a successful business without support of City funding.

This Request for Proposals is an invitation by the City of Toronto to prospective Suppliers to submit bids for the decarbonizing the public realm study. For the purposes of this study, the exterior public realm includes two categories: Right of Ways (inclusive of roadways, laneways, bike infrastructure, green infrastructure, transitways, sidewalks, and boulevards) and parks (inclusive of playgrounds, splashpads, urban plazas, trails, ravines, and all other types of parks).

This RFP is an invitation by the City of Toronto (the "City") to prospective suppliers to submit Bids for Professional and Technical Services for the Design, Preparation of Tender Documents and Contract Administration for for the Proposed State of Good Repair work at Don Montgomery Community Recreation Centre.

This contract includes, in general, the following work:   •	Provision of various shop drawings covering all aspects of the work, liner designs, installation procedures, safety plans and project schedules.  •	Procurement of specialized inspection contractors, materials, and fittings to facilitate the work to be completed.   •	Permitting, notifications to the public, and responses to concerns during construction.  •	Pre-surveying of properties and associated water meters and services.  •	Coordination of locates for watermain and underground utilities.  •	Implementation of traffic control on site.   •	Design and implementation of temporary bypass systems to facilitate the work.   •	Camera inspection (CCTV) of the interior of the watermain for pre-cleaning, post-cleaning, pre-lining, post-lining, and warranty purposes.  •	Test excavation pits for confirmatory purposes.  •	Excavation of access pits.  •	Where required, installation of new copper water services from the existing water main to the street line.  •	Dis-infection of watermain, fittings, CCTV equipment, and tools throughout the work.   •	Host pipe preparation, including repairs, cleaning, and field measurements.  •	Rehabilitation of existing watermains by installation of CIPP liners.  •	Sampling of CIPP liners on site and provision of third party testing.  •	Collection of resin samples. •	Reinstatement of services.  •	Wet-taps of existing watermains to facilitate new services.  •	Replacement of existing valves, hydrants, and fittings.   •	Replacement or rehabilitation of hydrant leads and existing service connections which are 100 mm and larger in diameter.   •	Recommissioning the rehabilitated watermain and pressure testing.  •	Complete Restoration.

Solicitation Document Description: The purpose of this RFP is to select a qualified professional multi-disciplinary team, led by landscape architecture discipline or architectural discipline, to provide full professional and technical services for Feasibility Study, Park Improvements, a Sport Dome, and the Targeted Net Zero Emissions Building of the Club House at the L'Amoreaux Sports Complex.   The objective of this project is to prepare feasibility study, develop a comprehensive design, and oversee the implementation of park improvements, a sport dome, and a targeted net zero emissions building of the club house at the L’Amoreaux Sports Complex. The successful Supplier will be responsible for preparing a feasibility study, a vision plan and phased implementation strategy, followed by detailed design and contract administration services to support the construction and delivery of key landscape and architectural program elements. This project includes both park and building upgrades and requires a collaborative, multi-disciplinary approach. The Supplier's team must integrate expertise in landscape architecture, architecture, structural engineering, civil engineering, and other relevant disciplines. The design must address accessibility, sustainability, long-term maintenance, operational efficiency, and alignment with City standards and community needs.
Wards: Ward 25 Scarborough-Rouge Park

Bids from USA Based Suppliers will be deemed non-compliant and rejected. .4	The Successful Supplier will be required to either (i) execute a Contract, or (ii) acknowledge the Contract as contained in the City's purchase order for the provision of the Deliverables. Suppliers should review the terms and conditions set out in Part 2 (FORM OF AGREEMENT) to understand the Contract being entered into with the City. It is the City's intention to enter into a Contract with only one (1) legal entity. The term of the Contract is to be for a period of one (1) year with an option in favour of the City to extend the agreement on the same terms and conditions for an additional term of up to four (4) additional separate one (1) year periods. .5	The City reserves the right, at its sole and absolute discretion, to not award some or all of the Optional Extension Years as part of the award of the contract to the successful Supplier, in the event that the cumulative cost of such Optional Extension Years combined with the cost of the original contract term exceeds the monetary thresholds established by the Canada European Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA). .6	This RFQ shall be interpreted in accordance with Section 3.14 (Definitions and Interpretation) and the City's Policies and Legislation. .7	Invitation to submit a Bid, including participation in any pre-qualification, request for information or other similar process or exchange of information prior to the RFQ, does not imply that a Supplier is automatically prequalified to meet the requirements of the RFQ or that the factors which were examined during such process or exchange may not be re-examined or re-evaluated by the City during the consideration and selection process for this RFQ. Solicitation Document Description: This RFP is an invitation by the City of Toronto to prospective suppliers to submit Bids for the Trunk Sewer Siphon Cleaning Project as further described in Part 3 of the Ariba event.  The City of Toronto's Toronto Water (TW) division currently manages, operates and maintains an extensive network of sewers that collect flow including combined flow, and ultimately convey the flow to several wastewater treatment facilities. These sewers are aging, accumulating sediment and deteriorating. It is the City's intent to clean selected siphon and gravity sanitary and combined trunk sewer pipes (600 mm to 2700 mm diameter), the associated maintenance access chambers (manholes), and to dispose of removed material. This also includes chamber repair/reconstruction and repair/replacement of mechanical equipment.

This nRFP is an invitation by the City of Toronto (the "City") to prospective suppliers to submit Bids for the Provision of Event Management Services for the FIFA Fan Festival 2026 in Toronto as further described in the nRFP documents. Suppliers may submit a Bid with respect to the following TWO scopes of work: 1) Site Production Delivery which encompasses the design, construction, delivery and operational management of the festival site and event, ensuring all infrastructure-including but not limited to staging, screens, audience areas, and hospitality spaces-is efficiently executed while adhering to safety, accessibility, and regulatory requirements. 2) Programming Delivery which focuses on curating and managing a dynamic lineup of live entertainment, cultural activations, and interactive experiences that celebrate Toronto's diversity while aligning with FIFA's global branding.

Solicitation Document Description: This Request for Qualifications (“RFQ”) is issued by the City of Toronto (the “City”) to invite Applicants to prepare and submit Prequalification Submissions to perform work for the Project using a type of construction management project delivery model for Gardiner Expressway Rehabilitation Project Section 5 - Cherry Street to the Don Valley Parkway project (GS5).    GS5 focuses on the realignment of the Gardiner and Lake Shore Boulevard East between Cherry Street and the Don Valley Parkway.   Major scope includes:   •	Construction of a new elevated expressway on a new alignment.  •	Realignment of Lake Shore Boulevard East from Cherry Street to the Don River including utility relocation.  •	Construction of two new ramps, connecting new Lake Shore Boulevard East to the Gardiner •	Construction of the North Linear Open Space north of the realigned Lake Shore Boulevard East.  •	Construction of a new seawall on the east side of the Don River between Sunlight Park Road and the DVP ramps  •	Rehabilitation of the piers and soffit of the Metrolinx Bridge over the DVP.  •	Demolition of the existing Gardiner structure.
Wards: Ward 10 Spadina-Fort York

Solicitation Document Description: The City of Toronto has four Accountability Officers - Auditor General, Integrity Commissioner, Lobbyist Registrar, and Ombudsman. Each Officer conducts in an independent manner the duties and responsibilities of their office and is appointed by and reports to City Council. Section 3-1.7 of Toronto's Municipal Code, Chapter 3, Accountability Officers, requires that "an accountability officer's office shall undergo an annual compliance audit by an external auditor appointed by and reporting to Council. This RFQ is for the supply of all labour, materials and equipment necessary to undertake Compliance Audits of the City of Toronto's Accountability Offices - Office of the Auditor General, Office of the Integrity Commissioner, Office of the Lobbyist Registrar, and Office of the Ombudsman for a five (5) year period for calendar years ending 2025, 2026, 2027, 2028 and 2029 (work to be completed in 2026, 2027, 2028, 2029, and 2030).
